# NSClipView

**Class**

An object that clips a document view to a scroll view’s frame.

## Declaration

```swift
@MainActor class NSClipView
```

## Overview

An [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView] holds the document view of an [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSScrollView], clipping the document view to its frame, handling the details of scrolling in an efficient manner, and updating the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSScrollView] when the document view’s size or position changes.

You don’t typically use the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView] class directly; it’s provided primarily as the scrolling machinery for the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSScrollView] class. However, you might use the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView] class to implement a class similar to [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSScrollView].

### Interaction with NSScrollView

When using an [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView] within an [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSScrollView] (the usual configuration), you should access the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSScrollView] properties that control background drawing state, rather than accessing these properties of the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView]. This recommendation applies to the following properties:

- [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView/backgroundColor]
- [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView/drawsBackground]

The [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView] methods are intended for when the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView] is used independently of a containing [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSScrollView]. In the usual case, [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSScrollView] should be allowed to manage the background-drawing properties of its associated [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView].

There is only one background-drawing state per [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSScrollView]/[doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView] pair. The two objects do not maintain independent and distinct [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView/drawsBackground] and [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView/backgroundColor] properties; rather, the accessors for these properties on [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSScrollView] largely defer to the associated [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView] and allow the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView] to maintain the state. Note that this state is not cached by the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSScrollView] object.

It is also important to note that setting [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView/drawsBackground] to [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/false] in an [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSScrollView] has the added effect of setting the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView] property [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView/copiesOnScroll] to [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/false]. The side effect of setting the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView/drawsBackground] property directly to the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSClipView] is the appearance of “trails” (vestiges of previous drawing) in the document view as it is scrolled.

## Setting the Document View

- **documentView**: The clip view’s document view.

## Scrolling

- **scroll(to:)**: Changes the origin of the clip view’s bounds rectangle to `newOrigin`.
- **autoscroll(with:)**: Scrolls the clip view proportionally to `theEvent`’s distance outside of it.
- **constrainScroll(_:)**: Returns a scroll point adjusted from the proposed new origin, if necessary, to guarantee the view will lie within its document view.
- **constrainBoundsRect(_:)**: Constrains the bounds of the clip view while the user is magnifying and scrolling.

## Determining Scrolling Efficiency

- **copiesOnScroll**: A Boolean value that indicates if the clip view copies rendered images while scrolling.

## Accessing the Content Insets

- **contentInsets**: The distance that the content view is inset from the enclosing scroll view.
- **automaticallyAdjustsContentInsets**: A Boolean value that indicates if the clip view automatically accounts for other scroll view subviews.

## Accessing the Visible Portion

- **documentRect**: The rectangle defining the document view’s frame, adjusted to the size of the clip view if the document view is smaller.
- **documentVisibleRect**: The exposed rectangle of the clip view’s document view, in the document view’s own coordinate system.

## Setting the Document Cursor

- **documentCursor**: The cursor object used when the pointer lies over the view.

## Working with Background Color

- **drawsBackground**: A Boolean value that indicates if the clip view draws its background color.
- **backgroundColor**: The color of the clip view’s background.

## Overriding NSView Methods

- **viewBoundsChanged(_:)**: Handles an [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSView/boundsDidChangeNotification], passed in the `aNotification` argument, by updating a containing [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSScrollView] based on the new bounds.
- **viewFrameChanged(_:)**: Handles an [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSView/frameDidChangeNotification], passed in the `aNotification` argument, by updating a containing [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSScrollView] based on the new frame.

## Views

- **NSScrollView**: A view that displays a portion of a document view and provides scroll bars that allow the user to move the document view within the scroll view.
- **NSScroller**: An object that controls scrolling of a document view within a scroll view or other type of container view.

## Inherits From

- NSView

## Conforms To

- CVarArg
- CustomDebugStringConvertible
- CustomStringConvertible
- Equatable
- Hashable
- NSAccessibilityElementProtocol
- NSAccessibilityProtocol
- NSAnimatablePropertyContainer
- NSAppearanceCustomization
- NSCoding
- NSDraggingDestination
- NSObjectProtocol
- NSStandardKeyBindingResponding
- NSTouchBarProvider
- NSUserActivityRestoring
- NSUserInterfaceItemIdentification
